p: Lactic acid bacteria, which have been used as feed additives for a long time, not only reduce CH 4 emissions per unit volatile fatty acid (VFA) output, but also improve the fermentation quality and fiber digestibility of silage ( Guo et al., 2020). In addition, the denitrifying bacterium Bacillus 79R4 could prevent NO âˆ’ 2-N poisoning and microbial ecosystems from impairing fermentation efficiency ( Latham et al., 2019). Furthermore, Bacillus licheniformis reduces CH 4 production and increases feed energy and protein utilization ( Deng et al., 2018). However, the inhibitory mechanism of lactic acid bacteria on CH 4 is still unclear; therefore, in the future, more research will need to be conducted on the influence of lactic acid bacteria on rumen microbes and hydrogen competition to elucidate the mechanism of inhibiting CH 4 production.
